items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Karen Poon, Director of Finance 
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to approve Charter School Proposition 39 Facilities Use Agreement with Alpha Public Schools - Cindy Avitia Charter High School
	 
	 
On or before November 1, 2015, the District received a request for reasonably equivalent facilities for the 2016-2017 school year from Alpha Public Schools – Cindy Avitia Charter High School (“Alpha”).  Alpha currently operates its charter program at the District’s W.C. Overfelt High School campus, and its current facility use agreement with the District expires June 30, 2016.  Alpha, like most of the District’s charter schools, is allocated facilities on a yearly basis by the District. 
	 
After consideration of Alpha’s request Administration proposes to enter into a one-year (2016-2017) agreement for continued Prop. 39 facilities for Alpha at the Overfelt High School site.  Unlike the Summit Rainier, Summit Tahoma, ACE and DCP charter schools, the Administration proposes a one (1) year facility use agreement for Alpha because Alpha’s future enrollment is expected to exceed current facilities and space availability at the current location.  The agreement is conditioned upon Alpha maintaining its charter in good standing and Alpha continuing to pay its pro rata share of facilities costs as authorized by Prop. 39.  The facilities include both “Dedicated Space” (classroom and administrative facilities for Alpha’s exclusive use in connection with its education program) and equitable shared use of other site facilities (including, for example, gyms, multi-purpose room, theatre, parking, athletic fields) to be used in connection with Alpha’s academic and athletic program, and for no other purpose.
	 
The Administration requests authority to negotiate and enter into a Facilities Use Agreement with Alpha for a one (1) year term in accordance with the District’s form Facilities Use Agreement (copy attached) subject to subsequent ratification by the Board.
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
To be determined. 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize Administration to negotiate and enter into a Facilities Use Agreement for charter school facilities with Alpha for a one (1) year term at the W.C. Overfelt High School site in accordance with with the District's form Facilities Use Agreement and subject to subsequent ratification by the Board.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize Administration to negotiate and enter into a Facilities Use Agreement for charter school facilities with Alpha for a one (1) year term at the W.C. Overfelt High School site in accordance with the District's form Facilities Use Agreement and subject to subsequent ratification by the Board.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Adopt Resolution #2015/2016-14 Urging the Legislature to Extend the Personal Beliefs Exemption Deadline to July 1, 2016
	 
	 
On June 30, 2015, Governor Brown signed Senate Bill 277, which eliminates exemptions from vaccinations for personal beliefs beginning January 1, 2016.  The elimination of the personal beliefs exemption is a major longstanding change in public policy. Many members of the public are not aware of Senate Bill 277’s effect as it relates to the mandatory exclusion of children from school unless the  exemption is made for medical reasons.  
	 
The California Legislature should amend Senate Bill 277 to extend the deadline to file personal beliefs exemptions to July 1, 2016, to make the effective date and operative date of Senate Bill 277 consistent and transparent to the public.  The attached resolution urges the California Legislature to amend State Senate Bill 277 to extend the deadline for filing exemptions for personal beliefs to July 1, 2016.  Furthermore, East Side Union High School District requests that the staff of the Santa Clara County Superintendent of Schools work with the Legislature and the State Board of Trustees to extend the deadline for filing personal beliefs exemptions to July 1, 2016. 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees Adopt Resolution #2015/2016-14 Urging the Legislature to Extend the Personal Beliefs Exemption Deadline to July 1, 2016.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Adopt Resolution #2015/2016-15 Supporting and Endorsing Strong Start of Santa Clara County
	 
	 
	 
Strong Start is a coalition of school districts, community leaders, early education providers, nonprofit organizations, elected officials, members of the business community and other key stakeholders who are committed to expanding access to high quality early learning opportunities for all children age 0 to 8 in Santa Clara County.​​​ Strong Start is currently introducing their coalition to all school districts in the County and encouraging them to use the flexibility and resources given to them by the Local Control Funding Formula / Local Control Accountability Plan process and the Every Student Succeeds Act to increase access to high quality early childhood education opportunities for the children and families they serve. 
	 
East Side Union High School District has already demonstrated its commitment to high quality early childhood education by taking many of the steps Strong Start is encouraging other districts to consider. Strong Start would like to expand its existing collaborations with the District by adopting Resolution #2015/2016-15 Supporting and Endorsing Strong Start of Santa Clara County.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees Adopt Resolution #2015/2016-15 Supporting and Endorsing Strong Start of Santa Clara County.

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve the 2016 Summer School Program
	 
In the Local Control and Accountability Plan (LCAP), the District has outlined Key Performance Indicators (KPM) related to student’s academic progress towards meeting A – G requirements. Our summer program is an integral component to support our students in meeting our KPM’s.  We will offer a program that focuses on creating a bridge from 8th grade to 9th grade.  In addition, we will offer a program that allows our current students to recover credits and accelerate towards higher-level courses. 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$750,000.00
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund, LCAP
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the board of Trustees approve the 2016 Summer School Program.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Julie Kasberger, Director of General Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation and Discussion regarding the Salad Bar Implementation
	 
In support of the State Superintendent of Public Instruction Tom Torlakson’s “Team California for Healthy Kids” and the national "Let's Move Salad Bars to Schools" initiatives, the Silicon Valley Leadership Group Foundation, along with partner organizations and member companies, raised money to provide over 100 salad bars to Silicon Valley schools over the past two years.  East Side Union High School District applied for and received 12 mobile salad bars. 
	 
Implementation of the salad bars started in the Fall of 2015.  The Santa Clara County Health Department regulations requires a room with four walls and a roof in order to serve food.  At this time, this has been one of our most challenging obstacles with the salad bar implementation.  Some very creative solutions are required to meet health code and implement the salad bars in all East Side Schools.  
	 
Salad bars implemented:
	 
·         Andrew Hill
·         Calero
·         Evergreen
·         Independence
·         James Lick
·         Mt Pleasant
·         Santa Teresa
·         Silver Creek
·         Yerba Buena
	 
Upcoming implementation:
	 
·         Piedmont Hills – point of service installation
·         WC Overfelt – point of service installation
	 
Schools that have been more challenging to implement the salad bars are:
	 
·         Oak Grove - Location
·         Foothill – Staffing
	 
	 
The salad bars have been a very positive addition to the Child Nutrition Services Program with many positive comments from students and staff.  
	 
	 
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Presentation item

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve Provisional Internship Permit Request for Certificated Employee
	 
Pursuant to State mandate, the Governing Board must approve provisional internship permit requests allowing the district to employ and assign teacher(s) or administrator(s) who do not hold appropriate credential authorization.
	 
The Provisional Internship Permit (PIP) was created in response to the phasing out of emergency permits and became effective on July 1, 2006.  It allows an employing agency to hire an individual who has not yet met the subject matter competence requirement needed to enter an internship program.
	 
The district is requesting approval of the following provisional internship permit request for the 2015-2016 school year.
	 
Provisional Internship Permit
	 
HUYNH, Dieu H.
Yerba Buena High School
Special Education M/M
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the provisional internship permit request for certificated employee as specified.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cari Vaeth, Associate Superintendent of Human Resources
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve New Teacher Hiring Incentives
	 
	 
California is in the midst of a growing teacher shortage.  The shortage is the reportedly the result of increased demand for teachers now that many school districts are receiving new, increased money from the state. To assist in recruiting teachers some school districts are now offering hiring incentives to newly hired teachers.  
	 
The impact of the teacher shortage is impacting the District’s ability to attract and retain highly qualified persons with credentials in the areas of Speech Therapy, Psychologists and Special Education.  The District has openings and is currently looking to employ four (4) teachers with the Speech Therapy credential, four (4) teachers with the appropriate Psychology credential, and eight (8) credentialed Special Education teachers.
	To assist in attracting new qualified teachers with credentials in those areas, Administration is recommending a new teacher hiring incentive of $2,500 to be offered to teachers with appropriate credentials in those specific areas only (Speech Therapy, Psychologists and Special Education) as an incentive to accept offers of 1.0 FTE employment with the District.
	 
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General fund
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Up to $40,000
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize and approve a new teacher hiring incentive of $2,500 to be offered to teachers with appropriate credentials in the specific areas of Speech Therapy, Psychologists and Special Education.

SUBJECT:
Approve Amended Effective Date of the Salary Schedule for Substitute Classified Employees
	 
	 
As per Board Policy 4262, Differential Pay for Maternity and Paternity Leave – Classified Service, the District shall adopt and publish a salary schedule for substitute classified employees upon which such differential pay shall be based.
	  
The classified employee shall be entitled to receive differential pay equal to the difference between his or her salary and the sum that is actually paid a substitute employee employed to fill his or her position and perform his or her duties during his or her absence or, if no substitute employee was employed, the amount that would have been paid to the substitute to perform such duties had he or she been employed. 
On February 4, 2016 the Board of Trustees approved a salary schedule for substitute classified employees with an effective date of February 1, 2016.  The district is requesting the effective date be amended to March 1, 2016, to provide time for notification of all impacted employees.
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be determined
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the amended effective date of the salary schedule for substitute classified employees to be effective March 1, 2016.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
	 
			 
			 
TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
						 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Receive Update on Independence High School's Growth Impacts and Mitigations 
			 
			 
On February 4, 2016 (Board Item 8.05), the Board received a presentation on impacts of charter schools on Independence High School’s facilities.  The Board approved long and short term upgrades to mitigate those impacts, and requested updates on the following items.
			 
Independence High School Athletic Facilities
The approved new practice infield and batting cages will be welcomed additions to the softball and baseball facilities, allowing more teams to practice concurrently. Baseball Coach Bob Leadbetter proposed the idea, and even mocked up a recommended location near the sand volleyball court with painted line markings, bases and pitching mounds.  The field could be dirt, and serve as both softball and baseball infields.  With the closely mown grass and painted markings, the area is already providing additional practice space for concurrent use with the existing two softball and two baseball fields.  The painted mock up demonstrates that a practice infield will fit – a concern voiced by Physical Education (PE) staff.  The mock up also demonstrates that there remains space for new batting cages behind home plate.  There is also space at the east end of the natural turf athletic zone for batting cages.  Independence High School staff will be highly engaged with the design of these new facilities, to ensure that the needs of PE, men’s and women’s athletics are optimized.
			 
			 
Another concern voiced at the February 4, Board meeting was that the soccer field layout is not as shown on the presentation.  The graphic showed two side by side soccer fields, parallel to each other and perpendicular to Mabury Avenue.  That layout is the optimized layout designed when the field was renovated in 2013; there are permanent markers at the corners of each field to facilitate repainting of line markings at the beginning of each soccer season.  Last year, one field was marked in differently just for the 2015 soccer season to accommodate storm drainage improvements that were underway.  Those storm drain improvements have been installed, and future soccer field layout will return to the optimized one indicated on the presented graphic.
			 
			 
Independence High School Staff Restrooms Near Building K3
The availability of staff restrooms near Building K3 Science Classrooms was an articulated concern at the February 4th Board meeting.  The closest staff restroom is in adjacent Building H – the former school administration building; that building is scheduled to be under construction beginning Summer 2016, and the modernized facility will be six classrooms and no restrooms.  Concurrently, new restroom buildings L6 and H2 are in design and will be constructed, with beneficial occupancy scheduled for early November 2016.  The graphic below indicates the designed locations of those new restrooms, which will be comprised of student and staff toilet facilities.  Those new facilities will be reasonably close to the Building K complex, and are intended to serve the occupants in Buildings K, L, G and H at the west end of campus.  
			 
			 
Staff investigated the possibility of adding a single staff restroom in Building K3.  The addition of a single stall restroom would impede upon program space that was renovated in 2004 (floor plan graphic below).  If encroachment upon program space is acceptable in order to accommodate a restroom, the rough order of magnitude cost is $500,000.  If program space encroachment is unacceptable, a single staff restroom addition outside of the building would cost $600,000.  Site administration does not believe the benefit of a staff restroom in Building K3 justifies the cost, particularly in light of the new Restroom Buildings L6 and H2 that will be available soon.
			 
			 
In 2014-15, ACE and DCP charter schools occupied Building H; they are currently no longer occupying Building H.  As of February 2016, Building H is housing McCarthy Building Companies, Inc. – the construction contractor that is modernizing Building B1.  McCarthy was directed to remove their construction trailer in the Theater Plaza upon completion of the Theater modernization project, to relinquish that area of the campus back to school operations.  In lieu of encroaching upon school operations further, the District is housing McCarthy’s project administration staff in Building H.  As of February 29, the staff restroom in Building H is also available for Independence High School staff.  This newly implemented interim mitigation measure is providing access to a staff restroom close to Building K3, until Restroom Buildings L6 and H2 open in November; however, this interim measure will not be available in the Fall 2016 semester, because Building H modernization construction will be underway.
			 
IH Theater Use Policy
The theater is available to be rented by both internal and external users.  Reservation can be made using the District’s on line reservation system (http://facilitron.com/esuhsd95133).  The request must be approved by site administration. If theater equipment is needed for the event, it triggers the additional cost of the Light/Sound Technician ($30.00 per hour, minimum of 3 hours).  No students are allowed to operate this equipment without adult supervision.  There may be additional charges depending on additional equipment needed.
			 
Fiscal Impact:
Not applicable
			 
Funding Source:
Not applicable
			 
Recommendation:
Not applicable
